Award.AwardTitle: A Single Particle Imaging Approach for the Detection of Virus Phenotypes in a Mixture

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1263701(Daniel). Technical part: The overall goal of the proposed research is to develop a single particle experimental platform for the identification and characterization of enveloped viruses based on their entry kinetics. This platform will integrate two key technologies: 1) single particle imaging of virus binding and viral-host membrane fusion of individual virion particles to a supported bilayer platform, and 2) statistical analysis of these individual events to discriminate populations based on variations in entry kinetic parameters. In this project, virus will serve as a model virus because it is one of the most studied viruses and thus the entry mechanism is well understood; its surface proteins are easily mutated and adapted to different cell types; it is well known that binding and fusion can vary among viral strains, e.g. H5 (avian) versus H3 (human) strains, and that these variations are correlated to infectivity. We propose that the rapid characterization of entry kinetics of virus samples from an infected person, made possible by the methods we employ here, can be used to determine which phenotypes the person (or a tissue sample) is infected with. In the case of influenza, this kind of rapid detection may be critical to promptly tracking the spread of virus during a pandemic outbreak or intentional release. In influenza, viral entry processes are controlled by the same protein, hemagglutinin (HA), which complicates decoupling binding from fusion in the overall entry kinetics. With current technology, it is only possible to assess separately, but not within the same virion, binding and fusion kinetics. This proposed platform discriminates between these processes within an individual virion, providing quantitative kinetic information on both processes that can then be used to identify phenotypes. Phenotype detection without PCR is currently a grand challenge in virus detection. Thus this is a potentially transformative technology that will aid in quickly discriminating among virus phenotypes in a mixed sample.

Non-technical part: This proposal will develop better understanding of how influenza virus subtypes enter the cell during infection. This understanding is important and authors postulate that it may be used to discriminate more harmful from less harmful types of infleunza. This project will therefore have significant societal benefit down the road by helping develop better influenaza diagnostic tools.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overall goal of the proposed research was to develop an experimental platform for the identification and characterization of enveloped viruses based on their entry kinetics. The approach taken was to examine individual virus interactions with host cell membranes in a platform that recapitulates the necessary elements in the natural infection process. These include a host cell membrane mimic presenting virus receptors and the ionic environment of the endosomal compartment of cells. Towards this end, this platform integrated several key technologies: 1) single particle imaging using high resolution microscopy of virus binding and viral-host membrane fusion; 2) a supported bilayer-coated microfluidic platform to control solution conditions, and 2) statistical analysis of individual events to discriminate populations based on variations in entry kinetic parameters. We used influenza virus as a model virus because 1) it is one of the most studied viruses and thus the entry mechanism is well understood for platform development; 2) its surface proteins are easily mutated and adapted to different cell types; and 3) it is well known that infectivity can vary among viral strains in different hosts. We proposed that the rapid characterization of entry kinetics of virus can be used to determine which phenotypes are present in a sample. In the case of influenza, this kind of rapid detection may be critical to promptly tracking the spread of virus during a pandemic outbreak or intentional release. 

 

In influenza, viral entry processes are controlled by the protein, hemagglutinin (HA). Phenotype identification without PCR is currently a grand challenge in virus detection. This platform discriminates individual viruses based on their HA functional characteristics and shows that these can vary extensively depending on the particular HA and its mutations. The scientific objectives of this research were: 1) Quantify & compare binding and fusion kinetics for native H3, H1 strains and egg-adapted phenotypes; 2) Develop virus-like particles to control specific HA mutations and particle characteristics, 3) Develop statistical techniques to identify phenotypes based on entry kinetics in a mixed sample.

 

To achieve these objectives, we compared binding and fusion of a significantly lab-adapted seasonal H3 influenza strain, X:31 (A/Aichi/2/68), to A/Udorn/307/72 (a less lab-adapted), and A/Brisbane/10/2007 (least lab adapted, mimicking a currently circulating clinical strain). We characterized each virus phenotype and showed that they are distinct from each other and that adaptation to different expression systems may promote these changes. Next, we developed a virus-like particle that was used to examine the impact of different influenza coat proteins and “recombinations” mimicking processes of reassortment in hosts, and found that virus fusion fitness is also impacted by the particular combination of HA and Neuraminidase (another influenza coat protein). Finally, we studied the fusion behavior of a recently emerged H10 strain and characterized its fusion attributes.  In addition, we developed supported bilayer mimics that are derived from host cell membranes, opening this technology to many other virus types that utilized complex or unknown receptors.

 

The intellectual merits of this research are creation of new methods to detect virus phenotypes in a sample in one assay platform. Identification is based on virus entry kinetics (functional assay) that vary due to adaptations of viral surface proteins, morphology, or membrane chemistry. Our approach employs a single particle imaging technique that discriminates between binding and fusion steps in individual viruses and provides a fingerprint signal that is used to identify phenotypes.

 

The broader impacts of this research are gaining a platform that can identify virus strains based on entry kinetics. Because phenotypes vary in infectivity, but are difficult to identify quickly using traditional microbiology tools, the approach proposed here offers advantages for virus detection of enveloped virus during critical pandemic outbreaks or malicious release. Additional uses for this technology extend to quality control in vaccine development or the characterization of antiviral compounds that target entry processes.

 

The educational broader impact inspired by this research was the development of a laboratory module on virus-cell interactions for outreach events for high school girls organized by the PI and students. This activity achieves several outcomes: 1) fosters rural tenth-grade girls’ interest in STEM fields and life science; 2) educates their parents about career options for their daughters in biotechnology; and 3) gives leadership and teaching opportunities to graduate students. It has directly impacted ~ 40 high school students and their families from the rural upstate NY area in the period of this grant. In that same period, approximately 8 graduate students (men and women) participated in organizing and executing the module. The response of the student participants was very positive and the module has been subsequently used in other outreach events.
